newsitem.title: HONG KONG: China brewer to use share issue to expand output.
newsitem.headline: China brewer to use share issue to expand output.

text.p: China's Tibet Lhasa Brewery Co Ltd said on Thursday it would use proceeds from its forthcoming domestic currency A share offer to expand production and market share in the remote Himalayan region.

The company would raise 79.1 million yuan in net proceeds from an initial public offering (IPO) of 25 million A shares for listing on the Shenzhen stock exchange, the firm said in a prospectus published in Shenzhen's Securities Times.
Beijing Securities Co was the chief underwriter for the IPO, to be priced at 3.38 yuan per share, the prospectus said. The offer would be launched on June 9 and completed by June 15.
Most of the share proceeds would be used to expand the firm's production capacity to 50,000 tonnes of beer a year in 1-1/2 years from the current 35,000 tonnes, it said.

The rest of the money would be used to build a production line for beer cans to replace the bottles that were easily broken after becoming brittle in the freezing temperatures that often hit the lofty Tibetan plateau, it said.
As the Himalayan region's only brewery, the company expected to boost its beer market share in Tibet to 50 percent from 30 percent, helped by increasing demand, it said.
The company posted a net profit of 15.2 million yuan for 1996 and 2.93 million yuan for 1995.

Despite a surge in earnings, the firm's profits were capped by an invasion of beers made outside Tibet and by poor road conditions in the largely undeveloped region that made long-distance delivery difficult, the company said.
After the issue, Tibet Lhasa Brewery will have 66 million shares outstanding, comprised of 41 million shares held by state institutions and 25 million A shares.
